title: Uninstalling Modules
description: How to remove modules installed by OmniSet.

sections.title: Removing Individual Modules
sections.content: OmniSet installs software using your system's native package manager. To remove a module, use apt (or your distro's package manager):
sections.code:
sudo apt remove <package-name>
sudo apt autoremove

sections.title: Common Package Names
sections.content:
Here are the package names for common modules:

- **docker** → `docker.io` or `docker-ce`
- **nodejs** → installed via nvm, remove `~/.nvm`
- **vscode** → `code`
- **chrome** → `google-chrome-stable`
- **discord** → `discord`
- **steam** → `steam`
- **vlc** → `vlc`

sections.title: Removing Docker Containers
sections.content: If you installed databases via OmniSet (they run in Docker), stop and remove them:
sections.code:
# List running containers
docker ps

# Stop a container
docker stop <container-name>

# Remove a container
docker rm <container-name>

# Remove all stopped containers
docker container prune

sections.title: Removing Snap/Flatpak Apps
sections.content: If a module was installed via Snap or Flatpak (fallback method):
sections.code:
# Remove Snap package
sudo snap remove <package-name>

# Remove Flatpak package
flatpak uninstall <app-id>

sections.title: Cleaning Up
sections.content: After removing packages, clean up unused dependencies and cache:
sections.code:
# Remove unused dependencies
sudo apt autoremove

# Clean package cache
sudo apt clean

sections.title: Configuration Files
sections.content:
Uninstalling packages doesn't remove configuration files in your home directory. To fully clean up:

- **VS Code** → `~/.config/Code` and `~/.vscode`
- **Chrome** → `~/.config/google-chrome`
- **Docker** → `~/.docker`
- **Node.js (nvm)** → `~/.nvm` and `~/.npm`

Remove these directories manually if you want a complete cleanup.
